title: Lightning Strike
summary: Emergency care for lightning strike victims. Lightning victims do not carry electrical charge and need immediate medical attention.

steps.title: Ensure Safety
steps.description: Move victim to safe area if lightning is still occurring. Lightning can strike same place twice. It is safe to touch lightning victims - they do not carry electrical charge. Call 911 immediately.

steps.title: Check Responsiveness
steps.description: Lightning often causes cardiac arrest. Check if person is conscious and breathing. Look for burns, especially at entry and exit points. Multiple victims: treat non-breathing victims first (reverse triage).

steps.title: Begin CPR if Needed
steps.description: If not breathing, begin CPR immediately. Lightning victims have good chance of recovery with prompt CPR. Continue even if person appears dead - lightning victims can be resuscitated after prolonged CPR.

steps.title: Treat Burns and Injuries
steps.description: Look for burns at entry/exit points (head, shoulders, feet). Cover burns with dry, loose dressing. Check for fractures from being thrown. Treat other injuries but prioritize breathing and circulation.

steps.title: Monitor and Stabilize
steps.description: Even if conscious, monitor closely - cardiac arrest can occur later. Watch for confusion, memory loss, personality changes. Keep person warm and still. Document all symptoms for medical team.

warnings: Lightning victims may have delayed cardiac arrest
Internal injuries may not be immediately apparent
Temporary paralysis is common but usually resolves
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for all lightning strikes
All lightning victims need medical evaluation
Seek care even for indirect strikes or minor symptoms
preventionTips: When thunder roars, go indoors - wait 30 minutes after last thunder
Avoid tall objects, metal, and water during storms
If caught outside, crouch low with feet together
